conclusion: Need to determine the ratio of the post-collision velocity to the pre-collision velocity using energy conservation and work done by forces.
Initial kinetic energy before hitting the ground is zero because the basketball is dropped from rest.
Potential energy at height H is mgh, converted into kinetic energy and work done against gravity and air resistance by the time it reaches the ground.
Kinetic energy just before collision is (1/2)mv^2, where v is the velocity just before collision.
Work done by gravitational force is mgh.
Work done by air resistance is λmgH.
Total work done by all forces is the change in kinetic energy, so (1/2)mv^2 = mgh - λmgH.
Solving for v, we get v = sqrt(2g(H(1 - λ) + h)).
Potential energy at height h after collision is mgh, and kinetic energy at maximum height is (1/2)mv_1^2.
Work done by gravitational force is mgh, and work done by air resistance is λmgh.
Total work done by all forces is the change in kinetic energy, so (1/2)mv_1^2 = mgh(1 - λ).
Solving for v_1, we get v_1 = sqrt(2g(h(1 - λ))).
Ratio of post-collision velocity to pre-collision velocity is v_1/v = sqrt((h(1 - λ))/(H(1 - λ) + h)).
Final ratio of post-collision velocity to pre-collision velocity is sqrt(h/(H + h - λH)).
